Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 53183-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
September 2019 
 
 
 
Strengthening Knowledge Partnership to Support 
Project Development 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank

In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) responds to the needs of South 
Asian developing member countries (DMCs)1 for innovative technology and crosscutting solutions 
to strengthen project preparation.2 
 
2.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  Strategy  2030,  which  emphasizes  strengthening  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) as a knowledge provider and expanding knowledge partnerships to 
support key operational priorities such as tackling climate change, making cities more livable, and 
promoting rural development and food security.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  South Asia is the fastest growing region in Asia—registering an average growth of 6.7% 
in 2018—beating the trend of slowdown and moderated growth in most of the developing Asian 
economies.4 Despite impressive economic gains that is expected to continue (6.8% in 2019 and 
6.9% in 2020), the region continues to face development challenges posed by the remaining 
infrastructure deficit, rapid pace of urbanization, and climate change. 
 
4.  In South Asia, one-third of the population lives in urban areas (31.0% in 2017), and this is 
expected to increase significantly to 48.6% in 2050.5 This rapid pace of urbanization, while 
creating huge economic opportunities, also presents formidable problems. Rural–urban migration 
has put pressure on already constrained infrastructure and basic services such as water supply, 
wastewater management, solid waste management, housing, and urban transport. Cities are 
becoming  more  complex  to  manage  because  of  the  need  to  simultaneously  address 
environmental degradation and massive shortfalls in urban infrastructure. Infrastructure financing 
cannot keep up with the huge demand brought about by the rapidly changing demographic, 
economic, and social development landscape. Transport infrastructure such as roads, railways, 
airways, waterways, and seaways are severely lacking or in poor conditions—hampering efficient 
movement of people, goods, and services in South Asia. Energy security is threatened with 
increasing demands from manufacturing, businesses, and households alike. Industrialization and 
related economic activities require sufficient energy supply to efficiently provide goods and 
services. The energy sector needs to keep pace to maximize potential economic gains while 
addressing climate change mitigation by promoting renewable energy and energy efficiency. 
Climate change, disasters, and natural hazards continue to threaten sustainable development in 
the region. Low-lying settlements along the coastlines are increasingly vulnerable to natural 
hazards. Water resources also plays a critical role in disaster management and food security. 
Natural hazards such as droughts, monsoons, heat waves, and earthquakes have caused 
significant loss of lives and economic damage. 
 
5.  ADB has been helping South Asian DMCs address these key development issues. As of 
2018, ADB has committed $84 billion to assist South Asian DMCs in sectors such as transport, 
energy, urban, education, and agriculture.6 However, much remains to be done to address 
persistent development problems. The region still needs substantial resources to fill infrastructure 
deficits, especially in lagging areas. Many still have no access to safe drinking water and lack 
                                                
1 South Asian DMCs consist of Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 9 July 2019.  
3 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila.     
4 ADB. 2019. Asian Development Outlook: Strengthening Disaster Resilience. Manila. 
5 ADB. 2018. Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
6 ADB. 2019. Fact Sheets. Manila.

2 
basic sanitation. South Asian DMCs still experience power outages that restrain economic growth, 
while underdeveloped transportation networks restrict the flow of people, goods, and services. 
Rehabilitation and better management and maintenance of infrastructure assets are essential. All 
of these need substantial financing though resources are limited.    
 
6.  Innovative technology and crosscutting solutions will be a key component to address these 
development issues. Integrating innovative technology into infrastructure and public services will 
reduce life-cycle costs and increase durability, improve the efficiency and quality of services, and 
minimize negative environmental and social impacts. Examples of urban sector technologies 
needed in South Asian DMCs include those for (i) nonrevenue water reduction; (ii) water treatment 
systems (arsenic and fluoride treatment, compact salinity treatment, end-of-pipe treatment for 
disinfection); (iii) digitization and monitoring technologies for distribution network; (iv) optimization 
of existing sewerage treatment plants (smart systems) with information and communication 
technology  and  artificial  intelligence;  (v)  sewer  cleaning  systems;  (vi)  pumping  systems 
optimization; (vii) segregation technologies in sorting plants; (viii) conversion of biodegradable 
waste to compost; and (ix) improving efficiency of integrated system of waste cycle. Examples of 
energy  sector  technologies  include  the  transformation  of  energy  audit  reports  into  energy 
efficiency  investments,  waste  heat  recovery  options,  and  floating  solar  power  generation. 
Examples of transport sector technologies include the intercity rapid rail transport and metro rail 
systems. Finally, examples of agriculture sector technologies include those for water resource 
management (irrigation systems, flood management, coastal management) and food standards. 
 
7.  The TA will respond to the needs of South Asian DMCs for innovative technology and 
crosscutting solutions to pressing problems by focusing on knowledge transfer from selected 
agencies  in  the  Republic  of  Korea  (ROK),  including  Korea  Water  Resources  Corporation 
(K-water), Korea Environment and Industry Technology Institute (KEITI), Korea Energy Agency 
(KEA), Seoul Housing and Communities Corporation, Korean Rail Network Authority (KRNA), and 
Seoul Metro. Knowledge partnership arrangements (without transfer of payments) with ROK 
agencies that have expertise in providing knowledge support for high-priority development issues 
in South Asian DMCs will be explored as needed during TA implementation.7 
 
8.  The TA focuses on agencies in the ROK because of  
(i)  its transformation from an aid recipient to a donor by achieving unprecedented 
economic growth within the past half century and its development experience and 
know-how, which offer a valuable resource for DMCs in South Asia;  
(ii)  its  level  of  technologies,  which—while  among  the  world’s  most  advanced—
matches the development progression of DMCs in South Asia;  
(iii)  its knowledge sharing program, which proactively helps developing countries 
achieve industrial growth and economic stability; and  
                                                
7 ADB has existing partnership agreements with several ROK agencies: (i) K-water with the Sustainable Development 
and Climate Change Department signed in May 2019 to promote water security in Asia and the Pacific; and with the 
South Asia Department signed in February 2016 to carry out technical study on water supply systems including 
nonrevenue water reduction; (ii) KEA with the South Asia Department signed in March 2017 under which KEA will 
provide advisory support to ADB’s energy efficiency initiatives and the energy efficiency technical support team in 
ADB; (iii) KEITI with the South Asia Department signed in March 2019 and will end in March 2022, to promote 
institutional cooperation between the two agencies in the areas of environment policies and programs, climate change, 
water resource management, waste management, and reduction, control, and monitoring of air pollution, among 
others; and (iv) KEA with ADB signed in June 2019 and will end in May 2022, to renew the general framework for 
cooperation and promote information exchange and knowledge sharing, and carry out joint activities on energy 
efficiency, renewable energy, energy access, and climate change issues.

3 
(iv)  its long and successful partnership and collaboration with ADB and its DMCs on 
various endeavors and initiatives. 
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: efficient infrastructure development and 
provision of quality public service by South Asian DMCs.8 The TA will have the following outcome: 
pipeline of projects with innovative technology and crosscutting solutions increased.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Analytical studies on innovative technologies and crosscutting solutions 
on areas of priority prepared. The analytical studies, such as pre-feasibility studies based on 
which South Asian DMCs can explore development partner funding, will focus on selected areas 
of ADB operations such as energy, urban, transport, and agriculture sectors. Possible topics for 
studies include solid waste management, holistic urban development, affordable housing, energy 
efficiency, and water resource management. Additional topics, which may be requested by DMCs, 
ADB resident missions, or sector divisions, will be included in the course of TA implementation. 
The studies will focus on use of cost-effective technologies based on successful experiences in 
the ROK. These innovative technologies and crosscutting solutions will be transferred to DMCs 
through training workshops with the goal of enhancing skills at the policy and program level.  
   
11.  Output  2:  Knowledge  on  innovative  technologies  and  crosscutting  solutions 
enhanced. This  will  involve  the formulation  and  conduct  of capacity-building  programs for 
government agencies and exposure visits to selected ROK agencies. The programs aim to 
develop technical expertise of the staff and improve institutional functions to deliver much needed 
services of international standards for citizens. Areas of such programs include water treatment, 
wastewater management, floating solar power generation, and intercity rapid rail transport and 
metro rail systems, to be provided by K-water and KRNA. Relevant technologies will also be 
disseminated through events such as roadshows, to be coordinated with KEITI.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and administered by ADB. The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
13.  The Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund will finance the TA 
activities including operational expenses in the form of consulting services; training events, 
conferences, and workshops; and other TA related activities. The TA will not be used for payment 
to  ROK  agencies  for  their  expertise,  civil  works,  procurement  of  large-scale  equipment, 
permanent staffing costs, and hiring of staff consultants.  
 
                                                
8  Defined by the TA. 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA  through  the  Regional  Cooperation  and  Operations 
Coordination Division, South Asia Department. ADB will engage individual consultants and 
organize workshops for the implementation of TA activities. The implementation arrangements 
are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  September 2019–August 2022 
Executing agency  ADB 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB  
Individual selection  International expertise  $150,000 
(10 person-months) 
Individual selection  National expertise  $100,000 
(16 person-months) 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time 
to time). 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.10 Consultants will be recruited individually because (i) they will operate in 
different countries; (ii) the timing of engagement will differ between countries; (iii) consultants will 
work and generate outputs independently of one another; and (iv) consultant management will be 
performed by staff of the Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division, South Asia 
Department.11  
 
16.  Selected ROK agencies will also be engaged to provide technical and knowledge inputs 
in the formulation of analytical studies such as pre-feasibility studies and other related reports that 
will support the identification of investment projects. They will also help in the conduct of capacity-
building programs including exposure visits and provide experts as resource persons. The TA will 
not pay for knowledge services, which will be considered in-kind contributions. However, the TA 
may finance per diem and travel expenses of experts from the partner agencies as necessary 
through resource person contracts. Implementation arrangements in working with ROK agencies 
will be governed by existing ADB policies and regulations.   
 
17.  Cofinancier requirements. Annual progress reports on project implementation will be 
prepared as required by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund. 
 
IV.   THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund 
for Strengthening Knowledge Partnership to Support Project Development, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board. 
                                                
10 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked of documents in Appendix 3). 
11 Use of output-based (lump-sum) contracts for consulting services will be considered.

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1.  Analytical studies on innovative technologies and crosscutting solutions on areas of priority  
     prepared 
1.1 Conduct consultation with South Asia Department sector divisions and resident missions to identify 
potential topics (Q3 2019–Q3 2021) 
1.2 Identify agencies in the Republic of Korea that can provide technical expertise for the conduct of 
analytical studies (Q3 2019–Q3 2021) 
1.3 Conduct review of literature and gather data to serve as inputs in the analytical studies (Q4 2019–
Q4 2021) 
1.4 Prepare reports containing findings of analytical studies (Q1 2020–Q1 2022) 
1.5 Present the findings of studies to stakeholders (Q1 2020–Q1 2022) 
 
2. Knowledge on innovative technologies and crosscutting solutions enhanced 
2.1 Consult with government agencies in South Asian DMCs to identify training needs (Q3 2019–Q3 2021) 
2.2 Conduct training and other learning events (Q2 2020–Q3 2021) 
2.2 Organize exposure visits in the Republic of Korea (Q4 2019–Q1 2022)
